text:
He had a formative
experience there. Towards the end of his
time at Rutgers, 9/11, you're not too far
so pretty formative.

Most of our students now
weren't alive on 9/11. But it was a big deal
when it happened. A couple people who
might have been alive.

I've seen a few gray
hairs but not that many. And so I inspired
to do something

and to defend our country
against the evil that happened, that day,
joined the SEAL Teams.

It was 11 years active. 11 years active. Yep. Long haul. It's like dog years at that
time and that kind of business.

So pretty extraordinary service
to pack a lot in 11 years. Came back and went to Wharton,
the Stanford of Pennsylvania.
[LAUGHTER] But got his MBA there. Went into VC.

Vista, right? Vista? Vista, yeah. Spent some time there. But when you have that call
to serve that he clearly

does and demonstrated when he
volunteered to go in the SEALs at a time of war. Said he wasn't quite maybe
scratching that itch.

So started this amazing
company called Saronics. And in just less than two
years, I think 20 months now,

you hit your 100th
employee just recently. I mean, the epitome of
hitting product-market fit.

And he's really killing it and
doing great things for America and everyone who supports him. And you're to hear more
of that story today.
But Dino, thanks for joining us. Thank you for having me. Awesome.

Well, Dino, why don't we
go ahead and get started? Can you tell us
a little bit more about the founding
story of Saronic?

You were an EIR at a VC. What were really those initial
days of getting Saronic

off the ground? Yeah. So when I decided to
co-found and build Saronic,

I was working at Vista. I working in private equity. I was out of the teams for
seven years at that point.

And candidly, I didn't want to
go work in the government again. That wasn't my plan when I
came out of the military.

And it was really
getting back to that, and as Joe said, being called
back into the defense space,

and really help build
products and solutions that keep this country safe that
led me to co-founding Saronic.

And I left vista. I just said, you know what? If I'm going to figure this out
and if I'm going to go and solve

this problem, I'm not going to
do it working 100 hours a week at a private equity firm.

It was a great job but it wasn't
what I was driven to go do. And so when I left there, I
was able to partner with Joe

Lonsdale and the folks at 8VC. They're a phenomenal
venture capital firm. But more importantly,
Joe was one

of the co-founders of Palantir. And so very experienced in
investing in defense tech,

also invested in companies
like Anduril and SpaceX. And passionate about building
the best products and solutions

and getting them into the hands
of the warfighters as fast as possible. And so it really
was that combination

of having that support system,
building out the thesis, identifying the problem, and
having the investors there

to support us with
the private capital to let us move very,
very quickly, once we've identified the problem, to
go in and execute on it.

And then you raised
$70 million-plus within a very short
period of time in the last two years, which
is quite an incredible feat

in Silicon Valley. I have a company that
just raised $100 million in the last two and a half
years and that's kind of the--

I would call it
the baby dragon egg unicorn in Silicon valley,
which is quite unusual. But how did you go
about that fundraise?

What was that process like? So Joe and the folks at 8VC have
really been supporters since

the beginning. So they led our seed round. And then Ray Tonsing
at Caffeinated Capital

came in, led our series A nine
months after our seed round. And really, it was because the
product-market fit that we had.

And you're really seeing
unprecedented momentum within the DOD now for
new types of solutions.

And it all comes down to
the urgency and the problem that we're facing as a country.

I tell folks all
the time, if you're going to invest in a
defense tech company, it's not that
dissimilar to investing

in a commercial company-- to have a clear product
gap in the market. You have to be uniquely
positioned to fill that gap.

And there has to be
demand to fill that gap. But in defense space, you have
to be really uniquely positioned

to fill it because there's
essentially one customer. And there has to be really,
really urgent demand

to drive action. That has to be a very strategic
problem for the Pentagon.

And that's where you
see a lot of movement and a lot of traction
within the defense space. That's why we've been able
to build this momentum

and investors have seen that. We've worked with the Navy
since pretty much the day we started the company to
understand the problem sets,

to understand the mission
profiles for our platforms and say, tell us what you want
to do with autonomous surface

vessels. What's the mission set? What's the problem you
have in the market? Why do you need them? Why can't you solve the
problem a different way?

Well, we're going to go
and build our platforms around the mission sets. And we're going to
build them from for you

to scale in the
quantities that you need. And that urgency, combined
with product-market fit,

has driven just a
ton of momentum. And you recently won your
first contract with the Navy

through an open solicitation. How did that come about? Maybe talk about just
landing that first contract.

Yeah. And so we signed two
CRADAs with the Navy within 90 days of
starting the company.

And for those of
you that don't know, a CRADA is a Cooperative
Research And Development Agreement. It basically lets you
partner with the Navy.

They're unpaid contracts. So we just said, we want
to work with the Navy. We want to understand
the problems

and the mission sets at
a very granular level. How do we get in there
and understand that?

Unlike doing diligence
on a commercial company, you can't just call
the military and have them tell you their problems.

You have to be under
contract in some sort of way. So we were able to get under
CRADAs, which, one, spoke

to the urgency and the
problem that we were solving because if there
were other solutions or it wasn't an urgent problem,
it's not something they would

see as necessary to go do. So we partnered with
the Navy to, again, build these platforms
and solutions.

And as that
transgressed over time, we did live demonstrations.

We've been out to San Diego
twice now as part of large Naval exercises where we've shown
our solutions in the water with

Naval operators to be
best in class technology, doing mission sets that
other platforms can't.

All of that, that
relationship has translated into what will now
become paid contracts,

meeting demand signals. And what are you learning about
your product and your team

from these initial trials at
these recent test and evaluation

demos and events? So the biggest thing
for Saronic is really

going back to the
partnership with the Navy. We have a very, very
close relationship

with some of the folks there. And it's seeing that industry
and military camaraderie where

folks are bought
into the mission and then understanding scale is
the way we solve this problem.

It's how do you build thousands
of autonomous attritable platforms that can be built
economically at scale to really

build the Navy of the future. So understanding, OK, then let's
bring that back and understand, OK, what are the
tactical missions that we

want to employ today. How do we build these up for
a Taiwan defense scenario

where we can provide
an active deterrence against an invasion of Taiwan. Then how does that evolve
into the Navy of the future.

How do we maintain Naval
superiority for decades to come?

So how did you go about hiring
your initial engineering and product team once you had
this idea for the company?

So I spent a disproportionate
amount of my time on early recruiting.

We're very fortunate to have an
absolute amazing founding team. Our three founders, Doug
Lambert, Vib Altekar,

and Rob Lehman are absolute
experts in their craft. Doug is our head of engineering.

He comes from a company called
Liquid Robotics where he was the head of engineering there. And then Vib ran
software at Anduril

where he ran computer vision,
sensor fusion, and autonomy across their product lines.

And Rob's our chief
commercial officer, where he was in the
Marines for five years,

and was [? at ?]
large primes, and then ran a consulting business
that helps businesses

And it was a lot of
my time, candidly, on LinkedIn searching
for folks and seeing

if they would get on the phone
and hear the story of what we wanted to accomplish and why.

And as folks heard the story,
and heard the investors that we had supporting us, and
heard about the founding team,

and the mission that we were on,
they really were drawn to it. And that first core 20
then attracted the next 20.

And it just started to snowball,
where as Joe mentioned, we have over 100 now, which is
pretty incredible 20 months in.

Yeah, 20 months in, wow. Maybe you could talk a little
bit about the early lobbying efforts as well and as you were
thinking about building out

that team as well. That's a fun story. So one of the things you have
to do in the defense space

is really build out that
lobbying effort, that government relations effort very early on.

It's not enough to just
go and build the best products and solutions. You've really got to build
those best relationships.

but maybe a week after
we started the company, we were literally
on Capitol Hill.

And I'll never
forget, our C deck had a picture of an
electric surfboard

with a quadcopter on top of it. And I was walking around
Capitol Hill telling congressmen

and senators, we're
going to change the Navy with this
electric surfboard that you see right here. It is an attritable
autonomous platform

that can be made
economically at scale. And this was before
you had built-- This was before
we had the built--

this is before we designed
the first product. So we did our first design
in partnership with the Navy

in January of 2023. So this design was something I
had come up with and was really

the foundation for the company. But I built an electric
surfboard out of a gun case

and did all of the
engineering in my garage. And then had some
artists render it to make it look like an actual product.

And then that was the
genesis of Saronic. Then we had very
talented engineers come and design the actual
things that could carry--

Make it look a little nicer. Well, it turns out that an
electric surfboard can't really carry that much weight and the
military cares about how much

it can carry and
how far it can go. So we built around-- it goes back to understanding
the problems that

how do you build to the
specs and the mission. Yeah. But lobbying early on
within a weekend was--

Within a week, yeah. And it's been critical. And it's one of those things,
again, similar to investors,

these are long-term
relationships that you're investing
in and support that's going to help
you for years to come.

I mean, a number of
congressmen and senators have now come to visit
our office in Austin.

They've made the trip from DC
because of the relationships we built with them and
their staff and the support

they have for our company. They want to continue
to be supportive. And ultimately that's
how we're going

to get more money allocated
to Saronic to go and build even better products
for the government.

Yeah. So we've seen a lot of success
with unmanned maritime vessels in Ukrainian conflict.

What is Saronic learning
from these lessons as you continue to build
out your platforms?

So we're obviously staying
very close to everything that's happening over there.

I'd say the most important
lesson we've learned is just seeing the effectiveness
of small unmanned surface

vessels play out real time
against a much larger fleet. I mean, Ukrainians
don't even have a Navy

and they've practically
immobilized the Russian fleet in the Black Sea. And so that is
very, very telling

for the capabilities of
these types of solutions. And then you learn tactics
and how they're employed.

And it's always going to be
a game of offensive versus defensive countermeasures
and how you continuously

evolve on the battlefield. What are some of your
biggest priorities right now as a founder and CEO?

So we are focused on
scaling manufacturing. So that is where, again,
going back to how do you

change the maritime battlefield. It's really through hundreds and
thousands of small attritable

systems. And it's not just
surface vessels. It's aerial drones,
it's subsea drones,

and it's how do you make
them all work together. We're focused on scaling
our manufacturing to get to that initial
ramp of hundreds.

And we're doing that
over the next 12 months. And we're also focused on
building and in a very open way

so that you can
work collectively with those aerial drones,
and subsea drones, and integrate with
the military's

existing communications
architecture so you can be employed
in the battlefield in a real meaningful way.

And where do you see Saronic,
say, 5-10 years from now? At the pace that we've moved
over the last 18 months,
a very large defense prime. Where we want to go is--

we really want to
focus on the Navy. And we see a lot of use
cases for the platforms

we're building today. So again, 3 surface vessels,
6 foot, 14 foot and 24 foot.

There's [? misses ?] in the
use cases for larger autonomous surface vessels as well. And the way we think
about shipbuilding,

when we think about Naval
power, can all be re-imagined. But then how do you get
into adjacent products

and think about advanced
manufacturing for munitions and how do we spin off
technologies that we're

building, such as automatic
target recognition or collaborative autonomy. There's a variety
of ways we can go.

And there needs to be a group
of new companies that come out and think about the problem from
a software-first approach that

is then enabled by hardware
versus the large primes that we have today that
are very hardware first.

And look, I don't
think we're going to see the day where aircraft
carriers, and DDGs, and cruisers

don't exist. But it's how do we support
those types of platforms. How do we extend their range,
capability, and survivability

so that we do have the most
powerful military in the world for a very, very long time. So let's take a step
back and talk more

about working with
DOD and government. You're a former Navy SEAL. We actually just hosted
another former Navy SEAL

and founder a few weeks ago,
Brandon Tseng of Shield AI here at Stanford. As you know, my husband
is also a former team guy.

He and I serve on the board of
Navy SEAL Foundation together. The question I always
have for former SOF

operators that are now working
on defense tech startups is, how has your
opinion of DOD, SOCOM

changed as you're now
working with government in such a different capacity?

If you asked me that
question six months ago, I think my answer would have
been a little bit different.

However, I'm really encouraged
by how fast the Navy has moved

over the last 12 or 18 months. And not just the Navy,
but the entire military

to acquire new
types of solutions and new types of technology.

I'll use the Navy as an
example because that's where we're focused on the most. Excuse me. But for the last
20 years, we were

involved in a ground war
in Iraq and Afghanistan. Folks ask me, did you
get the idea for Saronic

when you were in the Teams? And I'm like, no. I'm like, there's not a lot of
water in Iraq and Afghanistan.

And it wasn't really a priority. But as we shifted back into
a very different paradigm

where now global competition
is now a thing again and we didn't think it was going
to be for very, very long time.

Once there's alignment, and
recognition, and acceptance of a problem in this country,
we can move really, really fast.

And the government has
the mechanisms to do that. They have the contracting
vehicles, OTAs, and SBIRs,

and other things. They just need to utilize them. And they need to have the
support to utilize them. And what we've seen over
the last 12 months, which

I don't really
think was the case, I mean, even three
or four years ago,

was very, very rapid movement
to make sure that we have what we need to be successful.

That's quite an optimistic view. What do you think
the DOD could do

to improve how it buys and
improves new capabilities? I think they need
to continue leaning

into new types of companies
with advanced software and hardware that
prove to be the best

capabilities on the market. I mean, you've seen
this now, Anduril just won a massive contract called
CCA with the Air Force.

This is a huge indicator
from government to industry that if you are a
new company, and you

have best in class
technology, and you're solving problems in unique ways
that you can compete for and win

multibillion dollar contracts. I think that's what
the government needs to continue to lean into
because the more companies that

win those types of contracts,
that's going to funnel more venture capital dollars
or more investment

in general into the space. That's going to get even more
products developed faster

for the government so that our
war fighters have best products and solutions available. And at the end of the
day, that's the real goal.

It's like, how do we get our
war fighters the best products and solutions as
fast as possible.

Is there anything that
the US industrial base should be doing that we're not?

Investing more. Investing more. I mean, if you look
back in World War II,

I think our defense
budget was 15% of GDP. And we spend a lot of
money in defense now.

But on relative terms,
it's a lot less. I think we're low single
digits in terms of GDP.

And there's a lot of areas
that need to be bolstered up. Shipbuilding is one of them.

Munitions manufacturing. Our defense industrial base
needs the type of investment

that I think to scale
those dollars in terms

of order of magnitude,
I think that's where they should be leaning in. What has been the hardest thing
about building the company

these last two years and
take that, and what advice do you have to the next
generation of founders
looking to work with government?

I think the hardest thing
about building the company, for me, personally, it's
been the speed at which we've

moved at and just keeping
up with the business. And keeping up, for me, it's
staying 6 to 12 months ahead.

So if I'm not thinking
6 to 12 months ahead, we're already behind.

And at the speed at which
we're moving, that's difficult.

But it's necessary to be
able to dive into the weeds and then zoom back out. For the next generation
of founders, I would say,

one pull the thread on where
you're being called to go.

When I joined the Navy, I
didn't know where I was going.

9/11 happened and I said, I want
to go have an impact on this war on terror. I literally learned
about the SEAL Teams

from a Naval recruiter in
a strip mall in New Jersey. And there's a longer
story that I'm

sure the Team guys in the
room would appreciate. But he pointed me to a
retired SEAL two towns over.

He said, go learn about
the SEALs from this guy. He took me to the beach
in January in New Jersey

and made me jump in the
water just to tell me about the SEAL Teams. I mean, it was absolute lunacy.

But I'm like, I love this. This is great. And then you never spent
time in the ocean after that.

It was like some swimming. During training, yeah. During training, they get you
completely over the water.

But when I got out,
I also didn't know. When I went to start Saronic,
I didn't have the, OK, this

is the exact problem that
I'm going to go solve. It was very much a, well, I
want to have a large impact

on the defense space. How do I go about doing that? When I left Vista, I didn't
have investors or an EIR program

lined up with a VC. I just kind of went
about it on my own. And I actually went
down a different path

and was looking at a
cybersecurity solution. Was able to lay out
the diligence process, much like I would in investing.

And so pull on those threads. Understand the big
impacts you want to have. And then just go
ask the questions.

I tell the story about going on
Capitol Hill with the PowerPoint slide of an electric surfboard.

I was just waiting for somebody
to just tell me I'm an idiot. Be like, what are you doing.

But you have to be willing to
go out and have put yourself out there and then
hear the feedback

and listen to the feedback. With the first
company we went down, I listened to the
feedback, I'm like, OK, well, this actually
really isn't a company.

Then we started building
out the thesis for Saronic, started listening to
that feedback again. You're like, wow, this is a
really, really big problem

that needs to get solved. So put yourself out there,
listen to the feedback. And then once you build
conviction, just send it.

Send it. I heard a great quote
that, don't ask necessarily what the world needs, but ask
what makes you come alive.

Because what the world
needs is more people that have come alive. So I like that quote. So I want to share
it with you all.

But pull the thread,
put yourself out there, and then send it once
you build that conviction would be my advice.

That's a great quote. That's a great quote. Why don't we open it up
for questions right now?
Questions for Dino here.

Good afternoon.  You've raised some money now. And I imagine in the future,
you'll raise a little more.

Hopefully, a lot more. Yeah. And then you just need to
return the capital [INAUDIBLE]. That's right.

The investors don't
ask for it back. [LAUGHTER] Where do you think there's
a gap maybe in defense

investing if there is one? Is it more so in the
early stage world that we need more
activity, in the mid stage,

or do you think the late stage
needs to get more involved in this sector? You have a few PE funds
like AE Industrial Partners

out there that have done some
acquisitions like for [? Max. ?] Then you have some preseed
funds, seed stage funds maybe.

But where along
that journey do you think there needs to be
a double down of we need more here to ensure that this
whole thing works down the road?

So my view here is it kind of
needs to be across the board. Because if early stage investors
are going to get involved,

then you need later
stage investors to provide exit opportunities. For a very long time,
the only exit opportunity

was Lockheed Martin,
or Boeing, or Raytheon. As these early stage companies
like Anduril, and then Saronic,

and others are able to offer
exit opportunities for smaller companies as well, if private
equity comes into the mix

and then provides
private capital to be an exit opportunity for
early venture capitalists, that

could be another avenue to
grow these types of companies. I think it really needs
to be across the board.

But it also needs to be with the
realization of not every company

that starts is going to make it. The DOD likes to blame it
on the "valley of death."

And while the valley of
death is a real thing and it takes a long time to
win government contracts,

know, the reality
is in any industry, 95% of companies that are
venture capital backed

don't make it. I don't know if that should be
any different in the defense space because you need that
type of risk to spur innovation.

And the more capital that
comes into the space, the more innovation you have. If there's capital up
the stack, then you'll

have exit opportunities
for early investors and that'll give them-- that'll build their conviction.

For a long time,
investors didn't think they can make money
in defense because there was no exit opportunities.
Thank you. Hey, Dino.

For the threat picture
that you're seeing and the demand that you're
seeing for your technology.

I know a while back
Saildrone was getting a lot of hype in the defense.

That was much more of a
reconnaissance platform. Are you seeing a lot more
demand for being more

forward in the kill chain
in the maritime space, being able to have constructive
kills in the Maritime space?

And then also, are you
seeing a lot of challenges on the back end
with the US supply

chain facilitating the scale
that you're talking about? Yeah, great questions.

Definitely seeing
demand for, I'll call it, active engagement
in the kill chain

to provide a
deterrence at scale. There's a lot of--

there's a lot of
benefits that USVs have that you don't necessarily
get out of aerial drones

or subsea. And again, they should
all be working together. But you're seeing
a lot of activity

with use cases around those
kind of kinetic capabilities. With the supply chain,
there's multiple levels

to the supply chain. We've been very, very thoughtful
about how do we build out

a very robust supply
chain with US or Allied countries that can meet the
demand signals that we have.

And then also, how do we
have the private capital to prebuy inventory
so that we're staying ahead of the demand.

Those are things
that we can control. When you talk supply chain,
there's also elements outside

of our control. When you talk about access to
rare Earth materials and things

like that, that candidly needs
to be government and policy influenced.

Hi, I'm a student at
the business school. And I'm curious how you approach
the lobbying on the Hill that you talked about.

Whether it was more
traditional lobbying, like you were looking
for policy change? Or it was more
like sales and you

were trying to build
relationships and sell? How did you think about
selling on the Hill?

So initially, we were
focusing on sales, just building relationships, gaining
traction for our thesis.

Telling people not only that
we have the best products and solutions and why this
is going to change the navy,

but also that it'll solve
strategic initiatives for four-star admirals and
for congressmen and senators.

Why do they actually
care about our products. And then driving that momentum
so that you can get dollars

allocated to the customer. So that they can
buy your products and you can get that
initial foothold.

Now, as we build that
out, it becomes an effort to how do you build a
large-scale program of record.

How do you federate
these capabilities across the entire fleet. How do you put Saronic boats on
every single ship in the Navy.

Because the reality
is if you do that, you just 5 to 10X the
capabilities of the entire

fleet. You've extended the range
capability and survivability of every ship in the Navy.

And you've done it for the
cost of one destroyer per year, which takes six to eight
years to build anyway.

So it's a solution
that they need. And you need that
support across the Hill.

What we found is you really
have to build that momentum and build those
relationships over time.

If we went in and
just said, hey, we're going to build the next
autonomous destroyer, I don't know that we would
have as much traction

as we have today. But that's what we're
building towards. As a brief follow-up,
what did you

find that they cared about most? What was the thing that
when you got in the door and talked to them,
they really cared about?

The deterrence to China. 100%. That is the today problem
that the Navy needs to solve,

is how do you solve the
Taiwan defense scenario. And then once you
solve that, it's how do you transition into
broader military applications.

Again, going back to
how do we maintain the most powerful military in
the world for decades to come.

Thank you. I'm just not-- let [? him ?]
off the hook too easy, man.
Back at you.  I have two questions.

The first is when starting
any defense tech company, there's a question of dual use. Obviously, other
people buy boats.

How did you think about
other customer sets that might be quicker to buy versus
longer sale cycles with defense

tech? I like to find the
absolute hardest problem and then make it even harder.

I'm kidding, but kind of not. The Navy, historically, if
you read books about Lockheed

Martin, Skunk Works from the
'50s and '60s, don't do business with the Navy. Historically, they've just
been a really bad customer.

What that meant to me was,
well, that's the customer that needs the most help. So we went into it and
said, we understand defense.

That's what I'm
passionate about. That's how we built the company. We talked to all of our
investors, all of our employees,

and said really up
front, if you don't want to invest in a boat that's
likely going to blow up one day,

then this isn't the
company to invest in. And that's OK. But we focused on defense.

And we flipped the dual
use paradigm and said, we're going to go and solve
the problem for the DOD.

And if we do that, then there's
going to be directly applicable use cases in the
commercial market

where we can apply those
military-grade solutions. Portland Harbor security's
a great example.

But the reverse
might not be true. Thanks. And second question
is, obviously, you're

doing hardware and autonomy. Autonomy by itself
for small boats,

you could spend all
the money you've raised and really only make a dent.

How do you think about
capital allocation within the company in
terms of building the best product versus building one
that is software enabled, highly

intelligent? So we started again
with what moves

the needle on the battlefield. And it comes down to scale. It's like, if we can't build
1,000 14-foot boats or 24-foot

boats, it doesn't really matter. We can go and design the
coolest boat on the planet and we can write the best
software code in the world.

But if you can't put
all of that together and the end-to-end capability
